The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, includes an amendment to establish an interagency committee on dam safety to enhance coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, includes amendments to improve dam safety in the United States by updating strategic plans and establishing cooperation among agencies. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 aims to enhance dam safety in the United States by promoting cooperation with governmental entities in all states and developing technical assistance materials for dam security. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 is amended to improve dam safety by coordinating national efforts and implementing a plan for dam safety training. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 is amended to establish a Board to monitor dam safety in the United States and advise on national dam safety policy. The voting membership of the Board is amended to include 11 voting members, with 5 members selected from State dam safety officials and 1 member representing the private sector. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 establishes a Board to monitor dam safety in the US. The voting membership includes 11 members, with representation from State dam safety officials and the private sector. The Director may invite nonvoting members like National Laboratories or dam safety experts to participate in Board meetings. The Board established by the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 encourages effective dam safety programs and coordination among Federal and State agencies for the protection of human life and property in the US. The Director may establish work groups under the Board to assist in achieving goals related to dam safety programs. Travel expenses are also addressed in the amendment. The Board members representing Federal agencies can be reimbursed for travel expenses, including per diem, while performing services for the Board. Other individuals may also be reimbursed for travel expenses as specified in appropriations Acts. Each member of the Board representing a State agency, the private sector, and work groups may be reimbursed for travel expenses by FEMA, including per diem, while serving on the Board. SEC. 4. RESEARCH. Section 9(a) (33 U.S.C. 467g) is amended to include cooperation with the Board, support for development, maintenance of information resources systems for dam safety, and initiatives for effective public guidance. Initiatives for effective public policy and improvements in dam safety engineering, security, and management are included in Section 9(a) to guide the formulation of policies and advance dam safety. SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. The Act is amended to provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Section 11 is amended by removing subsection (a) and following text. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 13(a)(1) is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Section 13(a)(2) is also amended to reallocate funds accordingly. Section 13 is amended to allocate funds for research, dam safety training, and staff. $1,500,000 is authorized for research each year from 2003 to 2006, $500,000 for dam safety training, and additional funds for staff at FEMA. In 2006, FEMA is authorized to appropriate $600,000 annually for additional staff to carry out sections 8 through 10.
